title: 104_hr519
content: The Act titled "Freedom and Self-Determination for the Former Soviet Union Act" prohibits foreign assistance to Russia. Foreign assistance to Russia is restricted unless the President certifies to Congress that Russia's intelligence activities in the US are routine, they are withdrawing troops from Moldova, and not providing military assistance in the Transdniestra region. The activities of Russian troops in the Kaliningrad region and other independent states of the former Soviet Union do not violate sovereignty. Russia is not providing military assistance to Bosnian Serb units or the Government of Yugoslavia. Russia has stopped unilaterally demarcating the border with Estonia and is in dialogue with them. Russia is engaged in dialogue with Estonia to resolve a border dispute and is willing to submit the issue to international arbitration. Russia is not providing intelligence or military assistance to Cuba, Iran, Iraq, Syria, or any country acquiring advanced weapons. The Secretary of State has determined that Russia has repeatedly supported acts of international terrorism. Russia is in compliance with agreements on biological and chemical weapons, and is committed to reforming its economy towards a free-market system. In addition to requirements in subsection (a), foreign assistance for Russia in fiscal years 1995 and 1996 is contingent on the President certifying to Congress that Russia has ceased military actions in Chechnya, is committed to resolving Chechnya's status through negotiations, provided a full account of espionage activities related to Aldrich Ames, and reimbursed the US for expenses related to Rosario Ames. The President must submit a report to Congress each fiscal year containing these certifications. The President must submit a report to Congress each fiscal year containing certifications required for fiscal years 1995 and 1996 in unclassified and classified versions. At the beginning of each fiscal year, the President and the Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress detailing the foreign assistance provided to Russia, including the organizations receiving assistance, its purpose, and effectiveness. The report should also include an account of unexpended foreign assistance for Russia, as well as an estimate and analysis of capital exported from Russia in the previous fiscal year. The President must direct the US executive director of international financial institutions to oppose providing assistance to Russia unless Russia complies with specified requirements. The term "foreign assistance" under this Act excludes humanitarian aid, educational and cultural exchanges, assistance from the National Endowment for Democracy, and aid for weapons destruction. The term "goods or technology" is defined as in section 1608(3) of the Iran. The term "international financial institution" refers to specific organizations like the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, while the term "other independent states of the former Soviet Union" includes countries such as Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Ukraine. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to fiscal years starting after its enactment, with exceptions for the fiscal year of enactment.
